column1: #Text=From March 15 to 17 , the Canadian city of Toronto played host to the tenth Furnal Equinox , an annual event dedicated to the " furry fandom . "
#Text=Programming ranged from music to gender , science to art , covering dozens of aspects of the varied subculture .
#Text=The event 's featured guests were visual artists Moth Monarch and Cat-Monk Shiro , as well as the co-owners of US fursuit costume builders Do n't Hug Cacti .
#Text=The event raised nearly CDN$ 11,000 for Pet Patrol , a non-profit rescue organization in Kitchener-Waterloo , Ontario , run by volunteers .
#Text=This exceeded their goal of $ 10,000 , the funds needed to finish a rural sanctuary .
#Text=The furry community is well-known for their charitable efforts .
#Text=Along with direct donations , the funds were raised through a charity auction offering original artwork , and a fursuit design by guests of honour " Do n't Hug Cacti . "
#Text=Last year , Furnal Equinox raised funds for a farm animal sanctuary .
#Text=While only 10 – 15 % of people within the fandom own a fursuit
#Text=according to a 2011 study , event organizers reported this year 908 of the 2240 attendees at Furnal Equinox brought at least one elaborate outfit to the event .
#Text=The outfits are usually based on original characters , known as " fursonas " .
#Text=Guests of Honour Cherie and Sean O'Donnell , known within the community as " Lucky and Skuff Coyote " , held a session on fursuit construction on Saturday afternoon .
#Text=The married couple are among the most prominent builders in the fandom , under the name Do n't Hug Cacti .
#Text=The scale of their business was evident , as Sean had made over a thousand pairs of " handpaws " , costume gloves .
#Text=The couple encouraged attendees to continue developing their technique , sharing that all professional fursuit makers had developed different techniques .

#Text=They felt that they learned more from failed projects than successful ones , citing the Chuck Jones quote that " every artist has thousands of bad drawings , " and that you have to work through them to achieve .
#Text=Cherie , known as Lucky , recalled receiving a Sylvester the Cat plush toy from a Six Flags theme park at age 10 .
#Text=She promptly hollowed the toy out , turning it into a costume .
#Text=Creating a costume is n't without its hazards : the company uses 450°F ( 232°C ) glue guns .
#Text=They 're " like sticking your hand in an oven . "

#Text=Other programming included improv comedy , dances , life drawing of fursuiters , a review of scientific research by a research group at four universities called FurScience , a pin collector 's social , and workshops in writing .
#Text=The 3D printed base for a fursuit mask , incorporating in tiny screens as eyes .
#Text=The " Dealer 's Den " hall was expanded this year , with even more retailers and artists .
#Text=While many offered " furry " versions of traditional products , at least one business focused on " pushing the boundaries of fursuit technology . "
#Text=Along with 3D printing a bone-shaped name tag when Wikinews visited , Grivik was demonstrating miniature computer screens that could be used as " eyes " for a fursuit .
#Text=The electronic displays projected an animation of eyes looking around , blinking occasionally .
#Text=The maker has also developed " a way to install a camera inside suit heads , to improve fursuiter visibility . "
#Text=He hopes the tech would reduce suiting risks and accidents .
#Text=Without the need for eyeholes , fursuit makers would have " more options for building different eyestyles . "
